title: Is it truly rare for someone to be both a skeptic and open-minded? - Quora

response.answer_text: As TJ says. Being a skeptic does not imply that the person indulges in blanket disbelief of almost everything. As the developer of the “New Skepticism” philosophy, Paul Kurtz said… Skepticism builds on the “ground of the known”. When presented with a claim, or a statement, or something of the sort, the skeptic would be inclined to say…. “Show me the evidence.” There’s no reason to doubt everything. If I came in to work and told my colleagues that I’d seen a nasty traffic accident on the way to work, that would probably be accepted without question. No reason not to…. Hardly an unusual occurrence. But if I said the accident involved a tractor-trailer full of unicorns which had collided with a dragon crossing the road….. Well, that might raise a few eyebrows. To be “open minded” does not mean accepting every claim or statement at face value either.

No. Skeptical is not the same as closed minded, its merely being open to a claim being false or true, and being willing to explore and evaluate the possibilities… the opposite of closed minded. When a person CLAIMS to be a “skeptic”, but, is really just questioning things that, if accurately evaluated, would be information of value… such that they reject information of value, but accept any information not in conflict with/that supports their world view.. … they are really only skeptical of things in conflict with their world view… a different meaning of the term. Many people who reject real information because its in conflict with their world view, like to call themselves “skeptics”, because they are attempting to equate their rejection of meaningful data, with others’ rejection of their invalid data. :D
